statement_html:
Suppose that \(p(t)\) and \(q(t)\) are continuous functions on \((0,\infty)\). Find a particular solution to the inhomogeneous equation

\(ty'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = t^3 \quad t > 0\)

given that \(\displaystyle \{t, t^2\}\) is a fundamental set of solutions to the homogeneous equation

\(\displaystyle ty'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = 0\)
statement_latex:
Suppose that $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are continuous functions on $(0,\infty)$.
Find a particular solution to the inhomogeneous equation

$ty'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = t^3 \quad  t > 0$

given that $\displaystyle \{t, t^2\}$ is a fundamental set of solutions
to the homogeneous equation

$\displaystyle ty'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = 0$
statement_raw:
Suppose that <math> p(t) </math> and <math> q(t) </math> are continuous functions on <math> (0,\infty)</math>. Find a particular solution to the inhomogeneous equation

<math> ty'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = t^3 \quad  t > 0 </math>

given that <math> \displaystyle \{t, t^2\} </math> is a fundamental set of solutions to the homogeneous equation

<math> \displaystyle ty'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = 0 </math>
